Content:
Twain once said something like "The most sought-after prize is the envy of other men". It's natural to want "prestige", but chasing after it kind of misses the point of life, no?

If you haven't done so, I recommend working for a small technology company with a strong engineering culture, staffed by smart & competent people who have nothing to prove. Worthwhile problems are fractal -- there's almost always more there if you keep digging.

Author: pyre
Content:
Note that in the ScummVM case, Atari had no problem with the GPL'd code... until their lawyer informed them that Nintendo's API license didn't allow them to open source code like that. And in Atari's defense the code was outsourced two layers deep to some place in Eastern Europe.

i.e. Atari had no idea there was GPL'd code in there until they were notified. They were cool with keeping to the license until they realized there was a conflict with Nintendo's Wii API license... then they hunkered down and git tight-lipped.

That seems pretty normal. Once the lawyers realized that the company was probably in the wrong, they when into 'damage-control' mode to try and minimize the losses to Atari.

Author: arohner
Content:
Well, I can't comment about running barefoot, but I can comment about running in traditional running shoes vs. running in cleats. When I first started playing ultimate frisbee, I used running shoes because that's what I had. I got shin splits constantly. Within a week of switching to soccer cleats, with almost no padding, the shin splints went away and never came back.

It's also worth remembering that not everyone has been running heel first for years. Most of them haven't been running at all.

Author: pyre
Content:
Not necessarily. They would just have to pay a settlement and stop any future distribution of their product that contained GPL'd code.

e.g. They would pay $x to the rights' holder for the code and not distribute the code until the GPL'd version was replaced with a non-GPL'd version. or they would just negotiate a price with the rights' holder for a non-GPL license of the code. (this obviously gets murky when there are multiple rights' holders; especially in code where (major) patch submitters are not required to agree to hand the copyright on their code to the maintainer(s) of the codebase just to get their patch accepted)

Author: Bjoern
Content:
In my opinion, TDD is a double edged sword. Not only does it depend on the persons preference but also experience. [1]

For the experienced or good programmers TDD is a hassle and often results in less efficient code and often in less code. (read: less done in the same time). Later tests are written to cover the code which is of course arguable. [1]

For the beginning or (below) average programmers TDD is great as it often results in much better code quality and helps produce more robust code. [2][3]

Here is an excellent article about TDD and its aspects. http://use.perl.org/~Ovid/journal/38616

[1] TDD Effective or is it ? http://www.theruntime.com/blogs/jacob/archive/2008/01/22/tdd...

[2] In favor of TDD, http://collaboration.csc.ncsu.edu/laurie/Papers/TDDpaperv8.p...

[3] Indications that TDD increases productivity http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1070618.1070834

Author: raghus
Content:
That is quite optimistic.

Until the early 1990s, the import of gold into India was restricted by the government and there was a large delta in the price of gold within India compared to the rest of the world. As a result smuggling of gold was very profitable and most of the Bombay underworld dons were gold smugglers.

One fine day the government lifted this restriction bringing the price delta to near zero and rendering the smuggling of gold, rather a waste of time. You'd think all the baddies would now be dis-empowered. No, they just switched to extortion and whatnot and are just as powerful and rich today as they were before - just doing different things.

It's like the Willie Sutton story. Q: Why do you rob banks? A: Because that's where the money is.

These drug lords are not in the drug business because they have a particular fondness for the trade but because that's where presumably the easiest money is. If that avenue is gone, they'll try and do other things - extortion, smuggling, counterfeiting etc.

Author: DannoHung
Content:
I like spec based testing because I think the tests you end up producing with it are seriously useful and can actually help guide your programming if you think of the test names (not the actual test code) before you start coding, but I've never been able to actually write tests in full before coding.

I try to think about how I'll test something when I'm coding it (so that it's easy to test), I try to consider what I'd actually be testing in a given piece of code (so the concerns are separated), and I try to stick pieces near each other that are coherent (so they can use similar setup/teardown for a testing context as needed). But I don't have the actual test code down.

I'll fight anyone that says automated tests aren't wortwhile though.

The great programmers I respect easily got CS degrees without working too hard; you show up and submit your tests/projects using your self-acquired knowledge. You should also have a natural curiosity for the subject matter. I think this is why Google's strict GPA policies work for them.

Author: MicahWedemeyer
Title: Ask HN: Hosted customer support (for cheap)
Content:
I'm starting to drown in support requests for my site: http://www.obsidianportal.com I manage it with one other guy, and we get several emails a day with basic requests. Sometimes both of us answer the same email, other times we dodge it and it falls through the cracks.

Further, we set up a forum a long time ago for people to report bugs / request features. It was great...until we got popular and the influx of requests overwhelmed us. Now, we haven't checked in months and the thought of it terrifies me.

So, we're looking at using a tool for this kind of thing, and we'd like something that crowdsources it as much as possible. I know that sounds lazy, but we want to reserve our time for the stuff only we can do (like database edits) and leave the "I can't figure out how to X" to the crowd.

Any suggestions on tools to use? We're looking at GetSatisfaction, FogBugz, and TenderApp. If anyone uses these (or others) and has any very strong positive or negative feelings, I'd love to know.

Thanks, Micah

Author: Kadin
Content:
I've read that article before and I don't find it particularly convincing.

Implementing any complex piece of legislation is hard. Luckily there are people who specialize in that sort of thing -- we wouldn't be hiring computer programmers to do it, any more than we'd hire policy wonks to code something in C++.

If the political will existed to legalize and tax, the actual implementation details, codifying the regulations, wouldn't be trivial but would be significantly less of a hurdle than getting the legislative votes in the first place.

What it would probably involve is standing up a new government agency (either at the state or Federal level), or increasing the scope of an existing one, to administer and perform the regulation. That's not exactly black magic; there are actually consultants you can hire who work exclusively in the public sector, managing "stand ups" of new agencies.

Lots of things look like impossible tasks, if you're not familiar with them. Imagine what a complex piece of software, or the whole software-development lifecycle, the process of building a major piece of software, is like for someone who's totally unfamiliar with it. You could forgive them for thinking that building anything more complex than Minesweeper is totally impossible. But it's not, and there's a huge body of knowledge within the industry on how to do it right, and how to do it wrong.

The same thing exists within the 'industry' (and it really is an industry) of public policy. It's good to appreciate complexity, but not a reason to run screaming away from it. Marijuana legalization is an eminently tractable problem.

Author: jswinghammer
Content:
Inflation is an increase in the money supply. Rising prices are a side effect of that increase. The government has many reasons to hide and distort real rising prices including TIPS and just generally wanting to stay in power.

Inflation was directed by the federal reserve for 8 years at a record pace. When the fed lowers interest rates they in effect increase the money supply through the expansion of bank credit which is the primary means by which money is introduced into the economy.

Author: jemmons
Content:
Um, isn't Microsoft's whole business based on selling an OS that supports as many different varieties of hardware as possible? Specifically, in this very space, wasn't the whole point of "Plays for Sure" that there were a multitude of hardware devices made by a multitude of venders that interoperated with the Microsoft solution?

I'm going to go ahead and call shenanigans on your post. I don't think it holds up to scrutiny.

Now if you want to make an argument about how Microsoft hid APIs in it's operating system so that its office suite or browser performed better than anyone else's, or how it bundled its browser to try to use it's OS monopoly to strangle competition in another market, you'd have a point. But it should be clear how those are vastly different circumstances that cannot meaningfully be applied to the case of media jukebox made by company "A" and random hardware media player made by company "B".

Author: anigbrowl
Content:
FYI, an ounce is a lot of pot. I don't smoke all the time, but when I do I'd class myself as a bit of a heavy user, eg I prefer to get stoned every evening.

An ounce would last me about 2 months, that'd be about $350-400 (based on buying a smaller bag once a week). In the Netherlands, a similar/quantity/buying pattern would have been about $250. This unscientific analysis (but with a very large sample size...cough...) suggests the black market premium is about 30-40%.

Author: il
Content:
Well, first of all, most people don't smoke marijuana by the ounce lol. An eighth of pot is currently around $60 on the black market, and legal sellers would probably keep the price around the same to compete. Which means, even with a $50 an ounce tax, assuming prices stay the same, there are huge profits for sellers.

At the same time, pot is much cheaper than cigarettes for the user, since an ounce would probably last a casual smoker weeks or months.

Author: nostrademons
Content:
There're lots and lots of former startup founders currently working at Google. Andy Hertzfeld of Radius & General Magic. Joshua Schacter of del.icio.us. Brad Fitzpatrick of LiveJournal. Bunch of others whose employment and/or startups might not be known publicly. That doesn't even count the ones who end up at Google because it buys their companies.

It's not just famous people too: at least 2 or 3 folks I work with regularly are former startup founders, not including myself. Seems to be the new career path for bright aspiring programmers whose startups fail: graduate from college, start a company, fold up company, work for Google.
